title: How to Apply a Dry Rub to Steak

steps.title: Choose 3⁄4 inch (1.9 cm) thick cut steaks.
steps.content: Choose 3 ⁄ 4 inch (1.9 cm) thick cut steaks. The flavor of very thin steaks can easily be overwhelmed by a dry rub. Choose steaks that are at least 3 ⁄ 4 inch (1.9 cm) thick. Look for cuts of steak that are well marbled with little or no connective tissue. Great choices are ribeye steaks, t-bone steaks, New York strip steak, and sirloin steaks. [1] X Research source Thicker steaks may take longer to cook.

steps.title: Put your dry rub ingredients in a container that can be sealed with a lid.
steps.content: Put your dry rub ingredients in a container that can be sealed with a lid. Pour all of your dry rub ingredients into a container. Brown sugar, paprika, cumin, onion and garlic powder, mustard powder, chili flakes, cayenne, and thyme are some of the herbs and spices most commonly used in a rub. Add 1 tbsp (15 g) of each ingredient if you're creating a custom recipe. [2] X Research source You can also follow one of the included recipes.

steps.title: Shake up your dry rub to combine the ingredients together.
steps.content: Shake up your dry rub to combine the ingredients together. Put a lid on your container and make sure it is sealed. Shake up your rub to combine the spices together. Make sure they are combined evenly. [3] X Research source Use a fork to whisk the ingredients together if you are worried they did not get evenly combined.

steps.title: Apply a generous amount of rub to each side of the steak with your hands.
steps.content: Apply a generous amount of rub to each side of the steak with your hands. Work with 1 steak at a time. Grab a generous amount of spice rub from the bowl. Rub it into 1 side of the steak using your fingers. Cover the entire side of the steak evenly. Turn the steak over and apply the rub to the other side as well. [4] X Research source If you have a large cut of meat, use a spoon to sprinkle dry rub over it before rubbing it in instead of taking small handfuls at a time.

steps.title: Rub dry rub on the sides of the steaks.
steps.content: Rub dry rub on the sides of the steaks. Pinch a small amount of dry rub in between your fingers. Drop it carefully over the sides 1 steak. Use your fingers to rub the spices into the meat. Make sure all of the steak is covered, leaving no meat untouched. Rub spices onto the sides of the other steaks as well. [5] X Research source The more you rub your spices into the steak, the more flavorful it will be.

steps.title: Let the steaks sit in the fridge for at least 40 minutes or overnight.
steps.content: Let the steaks sit in the fridge for at least 40 minutes or overnight. Depending on how much time you have, let the rub sit on the steak for at least 40 minutes or overnight. 40 minutes will allow the salt from the rub to soak into the meat, while letting it sit overnight will allow the steak to absorb more of the flavor and spice from your rub. [6] X Research source Cover the steaks in foil or plastic if you will be leaving it in your fridge overnight.

steps.title: Cook the steaks until they are to your liking.
steps.content: Cook the steaks until they are to your liking. Use a grill, oven, or pan to cook your steaks. Flip the steaks about halfway through your cook-time to make sure they get evenly cooked throughout. Steaks can be rare, medium-rare, or well-done. [7] X Research source Save the rest of your dry rub for up to a month in an airtight container as long as it has not touched raw meat.
